üéØ General Principles

Objectives

  • ‚Ä¢ Readability: Easy to read and understand code
  • ‚Ä¢ Maintainability: Easy to modify code
  • ‚Ä¢ Consistency: Uniform code throughout the project
  • ‚Ä¢ Collaboration: Code understandable by everyone

Common Rules

  • ‚Ä¢ Indentation: 2 spaces
  • ‚Ä¢ Encoding: UTF-8
  • ‚Ä¢ Language: EN or FR (consistent)
  • ‚Ä¢ Max line length: 100 characters
  • ‚Ä¢ End of file: blank line

Best Practices

  • ‚Ä¢ Avoid global variables
  • ‚Ä¢ Use meaningful names

Directive .md file

  • ‚Ä¢ Use a directive file for your project

üìÑ HTML Standards

Basic Structure

Mozilla Guidelines (official reference)

  • ‚Ä¢ HTML5 doctype required: <!DOCTYPE html>
  • ‚Ä¢ Document language via lang on <html>
  • ‚Ä¢ Encoding: <meta charset="utf-8" /> (lowercase, self-closing)
  • ‚Ä¢ Viewport: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width" />
‚úÖ Complete HTML5 structure
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8" />
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width" />
  <meta name="description" content="Relevant description" />
  <title>Descriptive Title - Site Name</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css">
</head>
<body>
  <!-- Page content -->

  <script src="js/script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

Semantic Tags

‚úÖ GOOD - Use appropriate semantic tags
<header>
  <nav>
    <ul>
      <li><a href="#home">Home</a></li>
      <li><a href="#services">Services</a></li>
    </ul>
  </nav>
</header>

<main>
  <article>
    <h1>Main Article Title</h1>
    <p>Article content...</p>
  </article>
  
  <aside>
    <h2>Related Articles</h2>
  </aside>
</main>

<footer>
  <p>&copy; 2024 My Site</p>
</footer>
‚ùå BAD - Using only divs
<div class="header">
  <div class="nav">...</div>
</div>
<div class="content">
  <div class="article">...</div>
</div>
<div class="footer">...</div>

Attributes and Naming

Rules

  • ‚Ä¢ Attributes in lowercase
  • ‚Ä¢ Classes and IDs in kebab-case (words-separated-by-hyphens)
  • ‚Ä¢ Double quotes for HTML attribute values
  • ‚Ä¢ Alt attribute mandatory for images
  • ‚Ä¢ Boolean attributes: write without value (required, disabled, checked)
  • ‚Ä¢ Enumerated attributes: always include the value (type="submit")
  • ‚Ä¢ Use the literal character over HTML references where possible (¬© rather than &copy;)
‚úÖ GOOD - Correct attributes
<img src="images/logo.png" alt="Company logo" class="main-logo">
<button type="submit" class="btn-primary">Submit</button>
<input type="text" id="user-name" name="userName" required />
<input type="checkbox" checked />
‚ùå BAD - Incorrect attributes
<!-- No quotes, camelCase, boolean attribute with value -->
<img src=images/logo.png class=MainLogo>
<button type=submit class="BtnPrimary">Submit</button>
<input type='text' id=UserName required="required">

Comments

Rules

  • ‚Ä¢ Use comments to explain complex or important code sections
  • ‚Ä¢ Avoid overcommenting trivial code
‚úÖ GOOD - Useful comment
<!-- Main navigation: order defined by the design system -->
<nav class="main-nav">
  <ul>...</ul>
</nav>
‚ùå BAD - Trivial comment
<!-- Paragraph -->
<p>Welcome to our website.</p>

üé® CSS Standards

CSS File Organization

‚úÖ Recommended CSS structure
/* ===================================
   FILE: style.css
   =================================== */

/* ===== 1. RESET & BASE ===== */
* {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

/* ===== 2. CSS VARIABLES ===== */
:root {
  --primary-color: #3498db;
  --secondary-color: #2ecc71;
  --spacing-sm: 1rem;
  --spacing-md: 2rem;
}

/* ===== 3. TYPOGRAPHY ===== */
body {
  font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
  line-height: 1.6;
}

/* ===== 4. LAYOUT ===== */
/* ===== 5. COMPONENTS ===== */
/* ===== 6. MEDIA QUERIES ===== */

Google CSS Rules (official reference)

Selectors

  • ‚Ä¢ Avoid ID selectors ‚Äî prefer classes (IDs are hard to reuse)
  • ‚Ä¢ Avoid qualified type selectors (div.card ‚Üí simply .card)
  • ‚Ä¢ Classes in kebab-case, meaningful and concise names
‚úÖ GOOD - Selectors
.btn-primary {
  background: #36c;
}

.product-card {
  border: 1px solid #ddd;
}
‚ùå BAD - Selectors
#main-button {
  background: #36c;
}

div.product-card {
  border: 1px solid #ddd;
}

Declaration Formatting

  • ‚Ä¢ Space after the colon: color: red (not color:red)
  • ‚Ä¢ Opening brace on the same line as the selector
  • ‚Ä¢ Always end each declaration with ;
  • ‚Ä¢ Blank line between each CSS rule
  • ‚Ä¢ Alphabetical declaration order (recommended)
‚úÖ GOOD - Formatting
.header {
  background: #fff;
  color: #333;
  padding: 1rem;
}

.main-nav {
  display: flex;
  gap: 1rem;
}

Values

  • ‚Ä¢ Omit units after 0: margin: 0 (not margin: 0px)
  • ‚Ä¢ Include leading zero: 0.5rem (not .5rem)
  • ‚Ä¢ 3-character hex notation where possible: #fff (not #ffffff), #36c (not #3366cc)
  • ‚Ä¢ Single quotes for CSS values: font-family: 'Arial'
  • ‚Ä¢ Use shorthand properties: margin: 1rem 2rem rather than four separate declarations
‚úÖ GOOD - Values
.card {
  border-radius: 0.5rem;
  color: #333;
  font-family: 'Arial', sans-serif;
  margin: 0;
  padding: 1rem 2rem;
}
‚ùå BAD - Values
.card {
  border-radius: .5rem;
  color: #333333;
  font-family: "Arial", sans-serif;
  margin: 0px;
  margin-top: 1rem;
  margin-right: 2rem;
  margin-bottom: 1rem;
  margin-left: 2rem;
}

BEM Convention

BEM = Block Element Modifier

  • ‚Ä¢ .block - Main component
  • ‚Ä¢ .block__element - Component part
  • ‚Ä¢ .block--modifier - Component variant
‚úÖ GOOD - BEM nomenclature
.product-card {
  border: 1px solid #ddd;
  padding: 1rem;
}

.product-card__title {
  color: var(--primary-color);
  font-size: 1.5rem;
}

.product-card__price {
  font-weight: bold;
}

.product-card--promo {
  background: #ffe5e5;
}

Responsive Design (Mobile First)

‚úÖ Mobile First approach
/* Base styles (mobile) */
.grid {
  display: grid;
  grid-template-columns: 1fr;
  gap: 1rem;
}

/* Tablet */
@media (min-width: 768px) {
  .grid {
    grid-template-columns: repeat(2, 1fr);
    gap: 2rem;
  }
}

/* Desktop */
@media (min-width: 1024px) {
  .grid {
    grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr);
  }
}

‚ö° JavaScript & React Standards

Structure and Organization

‚úÖ Recommended JS structure
'use strict';

/**
 * FILE: script.js
 * Description: Scripts for [Project Name]
 */

// ===== CONSTANTS =====
const API_URL = 'https://api.example.com';
const MAX_ATTEMPTS = 3;

// ===== GLOBAL VARIABLES =====
let counter = 0;

// ===== UTILITY FUNCTIONS =====
function formatDate(date) {
  return date.toLocaleDateString('en-US');
}

// ===== INITIALIZATION =====
document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', initialize);

Naming Conventions

Conventions

  • ‚Ä¢ Variables and functions: camelCase
  • ‚Ä¢ Constants: UPPER_SNAKE_CASE
  • ‚Ä¢ Classes: PascalCase
‚úÖ GOOD - Consistent naming
const TAX_RATE = 0.077;
let productCount = 0;
let activeUser = null;

function calculateTotalPrice(priceExclTax, quantity) {
  return priceExclTax * quantity * (1 + TAX_RATE);
}

class ShoppingCartManager {
  constructor() {
    this.items = [];
  }
}
‚ùå BAD - Inconsistent naming
const taxrate = 0.077;
let ProductCount = 0;
var user = null;

function calc(x, y) {
  return x * y * 1.077;
}

DOM Manipulation

‚úÖ GOOD - Modern addEventListener
const submitButton = document.getElementById('btn-submit');
const nameField = document.querySelector('#name');

submitButton.addEventListener('click', (event) => {
  event.preventDefault();
  const name = nameField.value.trim();
  
  if (name === '') {
    showError('Name is required');
    return;
  }
  
  processForm(name);
});
‚ùå BAD - Inline onclick
// Avoid onclick in HTML
// <button onclick="myFunction()">Click</button>

React ‚Äî Defensive Rendering

Rendering Security

  • ‚Ä¢ Use React's default escaping: React automatically escapes JSX values
  • ‚Ä¢ Avoid dangerouslySetInnerHTML unless strictly justified
  • ‚Ä¢ If user-generated HTML must be rendered, use DOMPurify
  • ‚Ä¢ ‚ö†Ô∏è Client-side sanitization is bypassable (via Postman/CURL) ‚Äî true security must happen server-side
‚úÖ GOOD - Secure React rendering
// React escapes automatically ‚Äî safe by default
function Message({ text }) {
  return <p>{text}</p>;
}

// If dynamic HTML is required: DOMPurify is mandatory
import DOMPurify from 'dompurify';

function HtmlContent({ html }) {
  const cleanHtml = DOMPurify.sanitize(html);
  return <div dangerouslySetInnerHTML={{ __html: cleanHtml }} />;
}
‚ùå BAD - dangerouslySetInnerHTML without sanitization
// XSS vulnerability if content comes from the user!
function HtmlContent({ html }) {
  return <div dangerouslySetInnerHTML={{ __html: html }} />;
}

üîí Security & Privacy

üîí Secure by design, private by default, educational by nature.
Security and privacy are not "add-ons" ‚Äî they are core architectural requirements.

Privacy-by-Design

Data Minimization

  • ‚Ä¢ Collect only strictly necessary data
  • ‚Ä¢ Challenge the collection of any Personally Identifiable Information (PII)
  • ‚Ä¢ Principle: if you don't need the data, don't ask for it

Web Attacks to Know

Client-side Attacks

  • ‚Ä¢ XSS (Cross-Site Scripting): injecting malicious scripts into a page
  • ‚Ä¢ CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery): forged requests from another site
  • ‚Ä¢ Clickjacking: overlaying an invisible iframe to hijack clicks
  • ‚Ä¢ Double-clickjacking: a variant exploiting double-clicks

HTTP Security Headers

Defensive Headers (server-side)

  • ‚Ä¢ Content-Security-Policy: restricts allowed sources (scripts, images‚Ä¶)
  • ‚Ä¢ X-Frame-Options: DENY: protects against clickjacking
  • ‚Ä¢ X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff: prevents MIME sniffing
  • ‚Ä¢ Strict-Transport-Security: enforces HTTPS
‚úÖ Example of secure HTTP headers (Express.js)
// Using the Helmet middleware (Node.js/Express)
import helmet from 'helmet';
app.use(helmet());

// Or manually:
res.setHeader('X-Frame-Options', 'DENY');
res.setHeader('X-Content-Type-Options', 'nosniff');

CORS Policies & WAF

Concepts

  • ‚Ä¢ CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing): controls which domains can access your API
  • ‚Ä¢ Same-Origin Policy: a script can only read resources from its own domain
  • ‚Ä¢ WAF (Web Application Firewall): filters malicious requests before they reach the server

Client-side Sanitization ‚Äî DOMPurify

Principle

  • ‚Ä¢ Use DOMPurify to clean HTML before injecting it into the DOM
  • ‚Ä¢ ‚ö†Ô∏è Client-side sanitization is not sufficient alone: it can be bypassed via Postman, CURL, or DevTools
  • ‚Ä¢ True security must always be validated server-side
‚úÖ GOOD - Sanitization with DOMPurify
import DOMPurify from 'dompurify';

// Always sanitize before injecting dynamic HTML
const cleanContent = DOMPurify.sanitize(userContent);
element.innerHTML = cleanContent;
‚ùå BAD - Direct innerHTML
// XSS vulnerability!
element.innerHTML = userContent;

File Linking

‚úÖ Loading order in index.html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>My Project</title>
  
  <!-- CSS in order -->
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="css/reset.css">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="css/style.css">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="css/responsive.css">
</head>
<body>
  <!-- Content -->
  
  <!-- JavaScript at end of body -->
  <script src="js/utils.js"></script>
  <script src="js/api.js"></script>
  <script src="js/script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

‚úÖ Validation Checklist

‚úÖ To check before submitting your project

HTML

  • DOCTYPE present and correct
  • Meta charset UTF-8 and viewport
  • Semantic tags used
  • Images with alt attribute
  • Forms with labels
  • W3C validation without errors
  • Consistent indentation (2 spaces)

CSS

  • External CSS file
  • CSS variables defined
  • Consistent nomenclature (BEM)
  • Mobile First (media queries)
  • No !important (except exception)
  • Properties in logical order
  • Consistent indentation

JavaScript

  • 'use strict' at file start
  • const/let used (no var)
  • Consistent naming (camelCase)
  • Documented functions (JSDoc)
  • addEventListener (no onclick)
  • Input validation
  • Error handling (try/catch)

General

  • Logical folder structure
  • File names in kebab-case
  • No unused files
  • Optimized images
  • Tested on different browsers
  • Tested in responsive
  • Console without errors

üîí Security

  • Privacy-by-Design: data minimized
  • No CSS #ID selectors
  • No direct innerHTML on user content
  • DOMPurify used if dynamic HTML rendering
  • HTTP security headers defined
  • CORS policies configured
  • Data validation done server-side

üí° Final Notes

These standards are guidelines to help you write quality code.

What matters:

  1. Consistency: Choose a style and stick to it
  2. Readability: Your code must be understandable by others
  3. Scalability: Your code must be easy to modify
üí° Tip: Reread your code as if you were discovering it for the first time. If it's difficult to understand, it needs to be simplified!
